title: How long will Mass. residents have to wait until their power is restored?
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Over 100,000 customers in Eastern Massachusetts lost power after a blizzard on Monday caused widespread outages.
Eversource restored power to 170,000 of its customers, but 220,000 remained without power as of early Tuesday afternoon.
Both Eversource and National Grid expect some customers to remain without power until Thursday due to high winds and difficult conditions.

title: 15 prospects Patriots fans should know entering the 2026 NFL Combine
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: The Patriots hold 11 picks in the 2026 NFL Draft, including the 31st overall selection, to address roster needs.
Top prospects like WR KC Concepcion and Edge Zion Young are being eyed by New England for offensive and defensive upgrades.
Potential picks also include TE Kenyon Sadiq, known for his athletic prowess, and OT Kadyn Proctor for line reinforcement.

title: Malden school employee on leave after alleged ‘serious incident’ involving high school student
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: A Malden school employee is on leave after an alleged incident involving a high school student.
Malden police are investigating the incident with no details disclosed and no arrests made so far.
The employee works at Linden STEAM Academy, and the incident allegedly occurred outside of work hours.

title: These Mass. schools are closed for Wednesday, Feb. 25
author: Audrey Cooney
bullets: Many Massachusetts schools remain closed Wednesday, Feb. 25, due to a historic snowstorm dumping three feet of snow.
School districts closed include Attleboro, Bridgewater-Raynham, Brockton, and many others in the South Coast and South Shore.
Several schools like Canton, King Philip Regional, and Walpole are running on a delayed schedule following the snowstorm.

title: MBTA to (mostly) resume normal weekday service after historic blizzard
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: MBTA to resume regular weekday service Wednesday, except Fall River/New Bedford line operating on modified schedule.
MBTA General Manager thanks employees and riders for patience during storm recovery efforts.
Passengers advised to plan extra travel time; MBTA continuing clean-up and providing latest updates via app and social media.

title: Curran: Patriots could ‘explore options’ to potentially upgrade from Stefon Diggs
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Stefon Diggs' future with the Patriots is uncertain due to his $26.5 million cap hit and expiring contract.
Diggs, who had over 1,000 receiving yards in his first Patriots season, may face contract restructuring or release.
Patriots might explore acquiring a younger, cheaper wide receiver, considering Diggs' age and ongoing legal issues.

title: Mass. representatives, including minority whip, to skip State of the Union address
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Massachusetts Congress members, including Katherine Clark, will skip the State of the Union, citing President Trump's policies.
Rep. Ayanna Pressley plans actions highlighting immigrant children's detentions, while Ed Markey attends a People's rally.
Gov. Maura Healey reaffirms her focus on Massachusetts priorities despite Trump's State of the Union address.

title: Will Charlie McAvoy, Jeremy Swayman be back in Bruins lineup when they resume play Thursday?
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Charlie McAvoy and Jeremy Swayman's availability for Bruins' Thursday game is uncertain due to travel delays from the Olympics.
Team USA's gold medal celebration diverted McAvoy and Swayman to Miami, affecting their return to Boston.
If Swayman is unavailable, goalie options for Thursday include Joonas Korpisalo, who returned from the Olympics.

title: Could Trent Williams suddenly emerge as a free-agent target for Patriots?
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Trent Williams could become a free-agent target for the Patriots if released by the San Francisco 49ers.
Williams, a 37-year-old left tackle, earned five All-Pro honors and has a PFF grade of 91.5.
San Francisco may cut Williams, incurring a $34 million dead cap hit, to unlock financial flexibility.

title: Boston ends snow emergency parking ban; residents can use space savers until Thursday evening
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Boston's snow emergency and parking ban ended at 6 p.m. Tuesday after a blizzard dumped 17 inches of snow.
Residents using discounted garage parking must remove their vehicles by 8 p.m. to avoid regular charges.
Space savers must be removed by 6 p.m. Thursday, with enforced removal in South End and Bay Village.
